item.title: Japanese Hostage’s Mother Urges Islamic State to Spare Him
item.description: Junko Ishido, the mother of the journalist Kenji Goto, made her plea hours before a deadline for a $200 million ransom for Mr. Goto and another Japanese man.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Junko Ishido, the mother of the journalist Kenji Goto, made her plea during a hastily organized news conference in Tokyo on Friday, just hours before a ransom deadline.

item.title: Editorial: Silencing Authors in India
item.description: Perumal Murugan is only the latest target of the cultural vigilantes.
item.dc:creator: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: New Saudi Ruler Pledges Continuity After Death of King Abdullah
item.description: King Salman was speaking as regional leaders shifted their schedules to attend what news reports said would be a simple and traditional burial.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Japanese Hostage’s Mother Urges Islamic State to Spare Him
item.description: Junko Ishido, the mother of the journalist Kenji Goto, made her plea hours before a deadline for a $200 million ransom for Mr. Goto and another Japanese man.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Nigerian Voters Look to Ex-Leader Who Ruled With Iron Hand to Loosen Militants’ Grip
item.description: With a presidential election only weeks away, Boko Haram’s unchecked rampaging is helping to propel a former military ruler to the forefront.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: News Analysis: In Impeaching Ex-Premier, Junta Revives Thailand’s Divisions
item.description: The decision to prosecute Yingluck Shinawatra, who enjoys the support of the provinces, risks prolonging what has already been a lost decade of economy-sapping protests and coups.
item.category: National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Wider Chaos Threatens as Fighters Seize Branch of Libya’s Central Bank
item.description: The move, by one of the factions battling for control of the country, threatened to set off a scramble for the bank’s vast stores of money and gold.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The central bank branch in Benghazi. The bank, which has headquarters in Tripoli, is the nation’s last functioning institution.

item.title: Obama Not Planning to Meet With Israeli Premier
item.description: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel visits the United States to lobby Congress for new sanctions that President Obama opposes, the two leaders will not meet, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Obama with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the Oval Office during a tense visit in 2011. The two leaders have clashed on issues like Israeli settlements.

item.title: Former Thai Leader Impeached, Reawakening Tensions
item.description: Dormant political tensions re-emerged in Thailand on Friday when the military junta’s handpicked assembly impeached the country’s former prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Trial of 2 Ebola Vaccines’ Effectiveness Is Announced
item.description: Tests of drugs developed by GlaxoSmithKline and Merck are expected to begin in Liberia in two weeks, federal officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK

item.title: United Nations Memo: Modest Victory for Israel in Quest for International Meeting on Anti-Semitism
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly on Thursday agreed to a bid by Israel to host a first-ever meeting devoted to the rise of anti-Semitism worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: King Abdullah, a Shrewd Force Who Reshaped Saudi Arabia, Dies at 90
item.description: Abdullah was one of the world’s wealthiest and most powerful men, but a cautious reformer amid great changes in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia in 2007.

item.title: Salman Ascends Throne to Become Saudi King
item.description: Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud ascended the throne after the death of his brother Abdullah on Friday amid increasing strains on the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud in 2013.

item.title: Third Trial in 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombings in Africa Begins
item.description: Khaled al-Fawwaz, charged in the attacks in Kenya and Tanzania, is one of the earliest and most senior alleged members of Al Qaeda to be tried in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Myanmar’s ‘Black Zones,’ Illicit Chinese Commerce Is Said to Thrive
item.description: Recent reports about the possibility of Chinese citizens being trapped in Kachin State are a reminder of China’s dealings in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times
item.media:description: An image from a video shows Chinese citizens purchasing jade in Hpakant, Myanmar. The area is supposed to be off limits to all foreigners.

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: A Proposed Law Stirs Protests
item.description: Antigovernment protests in the Democratic Republic of Congo have left at least a dozen people dead, officials said Thursday, as the Senate postponed a vote on a proposed law that the opposition fears will prolong the president’s time in power.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Violence Erupts in Soweto
item.description: About 70 people have been arrested in the Soweto area of Johannesburg over protests and looting, much of it aimed at shops owned by residents from other countries, local news media reported Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: A Bird Flu Outbreak Spreads
item.description: An outbreak of avian flu that began in two states has spread to seven since last week and has infected more than 140,000 birds, Nigeria’s agriculture minister was quoted as saying by Nigerian news media on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: India: Court Orders Release of Activist
item.description: A court on Thursday ordered the release of an activist who has been on a hunger strike for nearly 15 years to protest a law that gives Indian security forces special powers to fight insurgents.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Attacks Hotel
item.description: A suicide car bomber blew himself up at the gate of a hotel that was being used by a delegation of Turkish officials on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
